metadata.title: Carbon nanomaterials enabled fiber sensors: A structure-oriented strategy for highly sensitive and versatile in situ monitoring of composite curing process

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Composites Part B
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/compositesb
Carbon nanomaterials enabled fiber sensors: A structure-oriented strategy for highly sensitive and versatile in situ monitoring of composite curing process
Sida Luoa,∗, Guantao Wanga,b, Yong Wanga, Ye Xua, Yun Luob
a Department of Material Processing and Controlling, School of Mechanical Engineering & Automation, Beihang University, Beijing, 100191, China b School of Engineering and Technology, China University of Geosciences (Beijing), Beijing, 100083, China
A R T I C L E I N F O

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Carbon nanotubes and nanofibers Graphene Smart materials Multifunctional composites
A B S T R A C T
Carbon nanomaterials (CNM) based technology has offered a variety of promising strategies for self-sensing and diagnosing functionalities in polymeric composites. In comparison with studies about detecting deformations and cracks, monitoring the manufacturing stage of composites using CNMs is rather limited. Based on continuous fabrication, we systematically investigated carbon nanotubes (CNTs) coated, graphene coated and carbon fiber sensors for monitoring complete molding process of composites through the real-time resistance change. Comparing to graphene-coated and carbon fibers with densely and continuously packed graphitic structures, the CNT fiber sensor with entangled and loosely packed porous network shows far superior performance for sensing different processing stages of composites, including resin infusion, gelation and curing. The resistance decay of the CNT sensor agrees well with curing kinetics measured by differential scanning calorimetry. Versatile capabilities of the CNT sensor were further explored for identifying various flowing defects such as dry spots and partially infiltrated areas.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The next-generation fiber-reinforced polymeric composites (FRPs) are impending to possess built-in functionality to continually monitor and diagnose their own health states. In addition to traditionally adopted technology for structural health monitoring (SHM), including metallic strain gage [1], metal oxide thin/thick film [2], optical fiber [3], piezoelectric [4], eddy-current [5] and magnetostrictive sensors [6], carbon nanomaterials (CNM) enabled sensors or sensor systems are emerging as one of the most promising technology for self-sensing, identifying, quantifying and deciding the health states of FRPs by virtue of excellent mechanical robustness, structural non-invasiveness, interfacial conformability and high piezoresistive sensitivity [7–9]. Basically, strategies to hybridize CNMs in FRPs include coating, depositing, sandwiching and mixing various types of CNMs, e.g. carbon nanotubes (CNTs), carbon nanofibers (CNFs), graphene, graphite nanoplatelets (GNPs) and carbon blacks onto/inside the surface, interlamination, fiber/matrix interface and resin matrix of composites. For instance, CNT twisted yarns [10], CNT/PVA coagulated fibers [11] and CVD grown fuzzy fibers [12] were explored as 1D sensors by assembling and embedding them in composites. CNM thin films [13,14], hybrid films
[15], coated/printed patterns [16,17], and freestanding papers [18,19] were served as 2D sensors by attaching them on surface or in between prepreg layers. Additionally, 3D sensors have been widely utilized by distributing CNMs particles in matrix to enable reinforcing and conducting dual-functionality [20,21].
The current CNMs technology for SHM applications of FRPs is majorly concerned for detecting deformations, cracks and failure modes in service stages of composites. Compared to service stage detections, advanced SHM technology for monitoring manufacturing stages of FRPs is equally important to detect and control events that may induce quality degradations and part-to-part variations during inline manufacturing process such as non-uniform flow front and problematic flow defects (e.g. dry spots) [22]. As a promising but incipient technology, CNMs for this purpose also have started attracting attentions and showing more benefits than traditional differential scanning calorimetry, dynamic mechanical analysis, rheometer and dielectric analysis in terms of mechanical robustness, embeddability and conformability, sensor weight, cost and implementation [23,24]. To name a few, Zhang et al. raised the possibility to correlate electrical resistance of CNT networks with properties of epoxy resin including glass transition temperature [25]. Gnidakouong [26], Lu [27,28] and Ali et al. [29]
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.compositesb.2019.02.067 Received 25 September 2018; Received in revised form 29 December 2018; Accepted 28 February 2019
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: s.luo@buaa.edu.cn (S. Luo).
Composites Part B 166 (2019) 645–652

sections.heading: Available online 04 March 2019
sections.text:
1359-8368/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
respectively utilized spray coated CNT networks, buckypapers and graphene coated fabrics to detect resin flow and cure states of polymeric composites. The obtained gain factors (percentage of the maximum resistance change) of the sensor are ∼160 [26], ∼240 [28] and ∼30 [29]. Applicable in both dry and liquid processes, our group also accomplished a series of works exploring CNT and graphitic thin film sensors coated on both single filament [30,31] and fiber bundles [32,33] to monitor resin infusion, gelation and degree of cure. The highest gain factor is ∼1600 [32].
Given the progress being made, the current CNM technology for process monitoring of composites is principally focusing on establishment of sensor fabrications and evaluation of sensor properties. The reported gain factors mentioned above are varied noticeably from ∼30 to ∼1600. Thus, one particular interesting and important question is: how do structures of CNMs in composites affect the behavior and mechanism of the sensor for in situ process monitoring? To elucidate this question so as to further advance this emerging field, this paper reports three different types of CNMs based sensors, namely, CNT coated fiber sensors (CNT-FS), reduced graphene oxide coated fiber sensors (rGOFS) and carbon fiber sensors (CFS) for monitoring the whole event of vacuum assisted resin transfer molding (VARTM) process of composites. Upon SEM imaging, we first observed significant difference on microscopic and packing structure of varied sensors. Compared to CFS with a continuous and densely packed graphitic structure, rGO-FS and CNT-FS with different nanoparticles coated on fiber cores respectively present a thin platelet stacking structure and a loosely packed rope-like network. As the packing structure changes from compact to loose, we observed the gain factor of resistance hierarchically increased from ∼7.5 (CFS) to ∼37 (rGO-FS) and ∼1600 (CNT-FS). This strong structure-dependent sensing performance was explained by different levels of resin infiltration to alter the tunneling resistance and density of conducting pathways in the sensor network. To better utilize the highest sensitivity of CNT-FS, the decaying resistance was correlated to DSC determined degree of resin cure under different processing conditions. Resultingly, the strong agreement inspiringly demonstrates the capability of CNT-FS for quality assurance. To prove this idea, local status of resin flow including partially infiltrated areas and dry spots has been identified by simultaneously monitoring five partitioned CNT-FSs.

sections.heading: 2.1. Fabrication and characterization of CNM sensors
sections.text:
CNT dispersion was processed by dispersing 300mg multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT, General Nano LLC.) in 100mL of deionized water with 8mL of Triton X-100 (CAS # 9002-93-1, Sigma-Aldrich) in an ice bath using a Ultrasonics FS-600N probe sonicator [34]. Graphene oxide (GO) dispersion was processed by dispersing 300mg GO (synthesized by the modified Hummer's method [35]) in 100mL of deionized water following the same setup. The sonicator was operated in a pulse model (on 10 s, off 10 s) with the power set at 480W for 1 h. The as-sonicated dispersion was then mildly centrifuged (Eppendorf Centrifuge 5418) at 3000 rpm for 10min to remove large bundles and aggregations [36]. A fiberglass roving (10m in length) extracted from the plain-woven cloth (290 g/m2, Easy Composites Ltd.) was selected as the substrate of CNT-FSs and rGO-FSs. A 15-cm long carbon fiber roving (200mg/m, Easy Composites Ltd.) was served as the CFS.
As schematically shown in Fig. 1(a), a continuous dip coating and fiber winding system was established for roll-to-roll fabrication of CNTFSs and rGO-FSs. The key elements for this system is composed of a computer controlled stepper motor and a series of pulley modules for conveying the fiber roving sequentially through a CNT or GO bath, a surfactant removing reservoir, and a heating station. The motor winding speed was set at 1 cm/min. After coating, CNT-FS was achieved with 15 cm in length. The GO coated fiberglass was further treated by a reduction process carried out by immersing the roving in a HI acid
solution (CAS # 10034-85-2, Sigma-Aldrich) placed in a thermostatic oil bath at 85 °C for 30min. The as-produced rGO-FS was cleaned in ethanol and water to remove excessive HI solution. The methyl orange and EDX methods were applied to confirm the removal of residual HI (Supplementary Figs. S1 and S2).
Structures of different sensors were examined by SEM, EDX and Raman. SEM was performed with JEOL JSM-7001F at 10 kV for examining morphologies and packing structures. The same instrument was used to acquire EDX spectrum for elemental analysis. A Horiba HR800 Raman microscope was used for collecting Raman spectra of varied sensors with a 532-nm excitation laser at the power of 5mW.

sections.heading: 2.2. Process monitoring of CNM sensors in polymeric composites
sections.text:
As illustrated in Fig. 1(b) and Supplementary Fig. S3, the fiber sensor was first manually threaded in a single layer of plain woven cloth with the trimmed dimension of 15 cm×15 cm along its center line. The sensing layer was stacked together with another two neat fabric layers. Assisted by silver paint, two copper electrodes were connected for electrical measurements. A resin flow medium and a composite release film were laid on top of the fabrics. A vacuum bagging film (WL5400, Airtech Ltd.) and a double-sided sealant tape were then used to seal the preform in a confined space for resin infusion.
Subsequent to sensor integration and preform lay-up, the resin infusion process was operated under 0.1MPa pressure in ambient temperature. Under vacuum pressure, pre-promoted (by 6 wt% of cobalt isocaprylate) and catalyzed (by 1.5 wt% of methyl ethyl ketone peroxide, Easy Composites Ltd.) polyester resin (IP2, Easy Composites Ltd.) was automatically infused, infiltrated and filled the vacuum space. The curing process was maintained for 24 h as recommended. During the whole process, real-time resistance of the embedded sensor was recorded by a Keithley 2450 Sourcemeter® programmed by a homemade LabVIEW user interface [37]. For multiple sensor recording, a Keithley switch control system 3706A-SNFP was assisted. For comparison, the curing process was also tested through DSC (Q-100, TA Instruments) by monitoring heat flow of resin.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text:
3.1. Structural characterization of varied CNM based fiber sensors
As described in the Experiment section, CNT-FS and rGO-FS were successfully fabricated through the continuous winding and coating process. The optical photograph of a pristine fiberglass roving, a GO coated fiber roving, and rGO-FS after the reduction process is shown in Fig. 1(c). Comparing to the ivory white color of the neat bundle, the ascoated GO fiber appears shiny grey; the as-produced rGO-FS shows a pitch-black appearance. Without the intermediate reduction process, the CNT-FS also shows a very dark appearance. The clear change of colors as revealed in Fig. 1(c) and Supplementary Fig. S4 (cross-sectional images) is a good indication of CNT/GO coating and GO reduction. It is believed that the capillary force formed by pores and microchannels in the roving would drag, trap and coat nanoparticles [38].
Following the roll-to-roll process, Fig. 1(d) shows an integrated fiber sensor in dry fabrics. It clearly demonstrates that the manual threading won't interrupt the configuration and fiber density of the woven fabric. In addition to single fiber integration, inset picture of Fig. 1(d) further demonstrates the scaled-up configuration of a 5×5 fiber sensor network for possible local mapping applications. The single and multiple sensor configurations were also demonstrated either in the course of VARTM process or in the cured composites (Fig. 1(e)). Owing to continuous and flexible fabrication and deployment, we can certainly expect that, with the assistant of automatic braiding instruments, this technique can be further scaled up for large-scale manufacturing of smart composites with customized sensor configurations.
In addition to visual inspection, morphology and microstructure of
CNT-FS, rGO-FS and CFS were systematically examined by SEM imaging. Fig. 2(a) – 2(c) unveil the microstructure of CNT-FSs under different magnifications. The low magnified images (2a and 2b) confirm the uniform CNT coating by observing the nanoparticles arrested throughout the surface of fiber cores. Additionally, the high magnified image (2c) restores the detailed packing structure of CNTs, in which the rope-like nanotubes were twisted and entangled to form a porous network. The pore size was visually estimated in the range from several
tens to several hundred nanometers. Similar to CNT-FSs, the graphene coating of rGO-FSs is also uniform and conformal as shown in Fig. 2(d) – 2(f) and Supplementary Fig. S5. Especially in Fig. 2(e), it clearly shows the ultra-thin and flexible nature of graphene with large lateral dimension that is able to cover the fiber surface with obvious ripple and wrinkle texture. Comparing to CNT-FS and rGO-FS with nanoparticles stacking on fiber surface, the CFS itself is the graphitized structure continuously and densely packed by a random arrangement of flat or
crumpled graphitic sheets with invisible voids [39], as shown in Fig. 2(g) – 2(i). In general, the CNT network is relatively loose-packed compared with flake-covering structure of rGO and continuous structure of carbon fiber.
To further examine the structure of various fiber sensors, Raman and EDX have been performed. In Fig. 3(a), comparing to featureless spectrum of neat glass fibers, the signature Raman features – D-band around 1360 cm−1, G-band around 1590 cm−1, and the two-component 2D-band around 2650 cm−1 have been identified to confirm the CNT or graphitic structures existed in CNT-FS, GO coated fibers (GO-F), rGO-FS and CFS. As an indication of GO reduction, the clear increase (from 0.27 to 0.58) in the intensity ratio of the 2D to G peak (I2D/IG) strongly suggests the restoration of sp2 carbon in rGO [40]. Due to the high percentage of sp3 carbon in GO, the reduction process was further proved by increase (from 1.13 to 1.28) of the intensity ratio of the D to G peak (ID/IG), relating to the quantity of structural defects [41]. In addition to Raman inspection, the EDX spectra (Fig. 3(b)) clearly show the substantial increase of the normalized carbon atoms from 12.21 wt % (Neat-GF) to 30.88 wt% (CNT-FS), 28.22 wt% (rGO-FS) and 22.39 wt % (GO-F), indicating the successful coating of nanoparticles. Again, the increased ratio of the carbon to oxygen peak from 0.49 (GO-F) to 0.75 (rGO-FS) confirms the effective removing of oxygen-containing groups. The key experimental results, including ID/IG, I2D/IG, weight percentage of carbon and oxygen, were accordingly listed in Table 1.
3.2. Sensing performance of varied CNM based fiber sensors
To reveal the valuable insights of in situ process monitoring of composites and explore the underlying structure-property relationship, sensing performance of varied fiber sensors were systematically evaluated and compared by collecting the real-time resistance change (ΔR/ R0) under 24 h for complete VARTM process under ambient temperature. Taking the first peek of the experimental data as shown in Fig. 4(a), ΔR/R0 of each sensor indeed changes accordingly as the elapse of processing time. Specifically, a rapid increase of ΔR/R0 was first observed at the beginning of the process for 10–20min. Followed
by another 40–50min, ΔR/R0 smoothly approached and stabilized to a crest value. As the continuity of the process, the ΔR/R0 started to decrease substantially and gradually leveled off for the rest of processing. It is clear that resistance of CNT-FS throughout the process shows the highest variation, about 2 and 3 orders of magnitude higher than rGOFS and CFS.
To systematically analyze the data, we divided the complete process into three stages: 1) Infusion stage (0–0.5 h) for resin injection until filling the pre-vacuumed bag; 2) Equilibrium stage (0.5–1 h) for the low viscous resin staying in the bag before gelation; 3) Curing stage (1–24 h) for polymer cross-linking after gelation. Fig. 4(b) first shows the sensor performance in the infusion stage. In addition to different value of ΔR/R0 in CNT-FS (0–1641.8%), rGO-FS (0–38.7%) and CFS (0–7.9%), the trend of resistance change in this stage is similar that a swift increase (0–0.1 h) of ΔR/R0 was first appeared (0–1090.5% for CNT-FS; 0–27.2% for rGO-FS; 0–5.34% for CFS) and then followed by a milder increase (0.1–0.5 h) approaching to the maximum (1090.5%–1637.3% for CNT-FS; 27.2%–37.9% for rGO-FS; 5.34%–7.66% for CFS). Specifically, the maximum ΔR/R0 of CNT-FS (1641.8%) in infusion stage was much higher than that of rGO-FS (38.7%) and CFS (7.9%); and their ΔR/R0 values respectively stabilized at ∼1600% (CNT-FS), ∼37% (rGO-FS), and ∼7.5% (CFS) at the end of this stage. Combined with previous works [26,28,32], we strongly believe the simultaneous inter- and intra-roving flow of the resin competes with each other to dominate the observed phenomenon. For the first 0.1 h, the resin was quickly introduced to wet the roving surface and fill the voids of the fabric. During this period, resin molecules would also penetrate and expand the conducting network of CNMs to alter their original structural configurations such as to increase the tunneling distance and break particle/particle contacts [42]. Thus, the initial resistance increased with high ramping rate. After filling majority of the inter-roving voids, the resin would continuously infiltrate intra rovings with a much lowered impregnation speed because of the micro- or nanoscaled intra-roving space [20]. As a result, the conducting network was mildly interrupted.
Following the infusion stage, Fig. 4(c) shows the electrical behavior of the equilibrium stage. It can be seen that the value of ΔR/R0 from 0.5 to 1 h for all sensors kept almost constant after it reached the maximum. This clearly suggests the end of resin flow so the sensor and the surrounding resin were basically staying in an equilibrium state. Although the viscoelastic property of resin was still changing, the low viscous and low cross-linked structure of resin would not further interrupt the configuration of sensing network.
Right after the infusion stage, the resistance of sensors started decreasing, which can be seen in Fig. 4(d). Confirmed by the identical upturn moment of damping factor, Lu's recent work argued that the resistance decaying of CNT paper is related to gelation time [28]. Based on this significant discovery, we further attributed the complete
decaying behavior of CNM sensors to the physical/chemical changes in cross-linking reaction as well as the development of matrix shrinkage (∼8% determined in Supplementary Fig. S6) caused by phase change of gelation and vitrification. To specify, drastic increases of viscosity and volumetric shrinkage were concomitantly happening after gelation of resin with high levels of cross-linking density [43]. Consequently, the inflated sensing network with infiltrated resin would shrink constantly to cause conductive particles and paths closing together with improved electron transport [44]. Accordingly, the ΔR/R0 was respectively decaying in CNT-FS (from 1594.8% to 517.8%), rGO-FS (from 36.36% to 27.38%) and CFS (from 7.43% to 3.99%) after 4 h of gelation. As slowing down of curing for rest of the process, it is thus straightforward to expect a gentle decay of ΔR/R0 from 5 h to 24 h. Fig. 4(d) indeed shows the intended electrical behavior in CNT-FS (from 517.8% to 399.5%) and CFS (from 3.99% to 3.23%). For rGO-FS, nevertheless, an interesting increase of ΔR/R0 has been observed from 27.38% to 34.18%. With the rationale of graphene with ultrathin and flexible nature, we believe the shrink effect of resin cross-linking would cause internal stress to compress and deform the fiber as well as the stacked graphene nanosheets. As a result, fissures and ruptures may be introduced in the graphene network to degrade its electrical property. Based on five resistance monitoring tests of CNT-FS and rGO-FS with low standard deviations, excellent repeatability of sensor performance was also evidenced. The result is shown in Supplementary Fig. S7 and Table S1. Exothermic heat dependent resistance change was also discussed in Supplementary Fig. S8, showing negligible effect on curing monitoring.
3.3. Structure dependent sensing mechanism of varied CNM based fiber sensors
Based on comparative study of microstructure and performance, we are confident about the existence of an underlying structure-property relationship in fiber sensors assembled by different CNM strategies. For one thing, the structure of conducting network is formed by packing of particles or fibers, so they are subjected to dynamic structural swelling and shrinkage as resin infusion and curing. For another thing, the micro- and nano-scaled structural properties, such as particle dimension, pore size distribution, packing density and coating thickness are vastly different. This will inevitably result in different degrees of resin infiltration to interrupt geometrical structure of the conducting network. To elucidate this idea, Fig. 5(a) shows the schematics to illustrate the structure dependent sensing mechanism(s). For CNT-FS, it is naturally easy for resin molecules to migrate into the conducting network due to the comparatively loose-packed structure with big pores. Thus, the achieved sensitivity is the highest. For rGO-FS, only a small portion of resin molecules can penetrate into the fissure-like gap between the overlapped flakes to cause a much weaker inflation effect, because of large lateral dimension and poreless nature of graphene. For CFS, its graphitic structure is continuous and densely-packed with negligible voids, so resin molecules could hardly penetrate.
To further corroborate the proposed mechanism, we summarized all the available literatures with the closest topic and categorized the sensor into 5 species, i.e., carbon fiber (CF), reduced graphene oxide (rGO), graphite nanoplatelet (GNP), buckypaper (BP) and carbon nanotube (CNT). In addition to CF, rGO and CNT that were studied in current work, the GNP packed network (inset image of Fig. 5(b)) shows like a stacked and rigid mosaic structure clearly with larger gaps than
rGO [31]. As for BP, its packing structure is much denser than the thin coated CNT film with the pore size distribution mostly in the range of 30–40 nm (inset of Fig. 5(b)) [27]. To better compare the sensitivity, we defined the highest resistance change (Rmax-R0)/R0 as the gain factor (GF) to quantify the performance. By summarizing this quantity extracted from relevant references, Fig. 5(b) clearly demonstrates the hierarchical performance of sensors assembled by different materials and structures. With the rationale of the discussed mechanism, the capability of sensors for in situ process monitoring of composites can be reasonably ranked as CNT (GF∼ 1000–2000%) > BP & GNP (GF∼ 100–300%) > rGO (GF∼ 20–50%) > CF (GF∼ 5–10%).
3.4. Applications of CNT based fiber sensors
To better utilize the high sensitivity of CNT-FSs for in situ curing monitoring, we correlated its electrical property to calorimetric property of resin for assessing curing kinetics to study effects of temperature and time on the degree of resin curing α(t). For this purpose, a wellacknowledged isothermal approach of differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) has been assisted to quantify the normalized accumulative heat of exothermic reaction, α(t), which follows
∫= ⎛ ⎝ ⎞ ⎠ = Δ Δ Δ α(t) 1 H dH dt dt H (t) Htot 0
t i
tot (1)
where ΔHi(t) is the partial heat of reaction at a certain time and ΔHtot is
the total heat of reaction. Calculated by Equation (1), the inset plot of Fig. 6(a) compares the degree of cure (α) as a function of time under ambient (∼25 °C) and high (60 °C) temperature. It is clear that the high curing temperature (dashed line) introduced a much quicker conversion of α than the ambient condition (solid line) because of the elevated mobility and diffusion rate of resin molecules to expedite the crosslinking reaction. As a comparison, it is equally interesting that the normalized sensor resistance under the high temperature also decays in a much faster rate, as shown in Fig. 6(a). Additionally, one should notice the high similarity of the two methods showing a rapid ramping (decaying) of data followed by a gradual leveling. To better convey the sensor's capability for measuring degree of cure, we reshaped the resistance data to the format describing the extent of decay, which was defined as:
= − − Δ Δ Δ Δ D(t) R R(t) R R i
i f (2)
where D(t) denotes the degree of decay; ΔRi and ΔRf are respectively the initial and final resistance during the curing process. As clearly demonstrated in both Fig. 6(b) and its inset, the sensor signal (red curves) indeed preserves a strong correlation with DSC results (blue curves) for disclosing degree of cure.
To further illustrate the correlation between DSC and resistance measurement, we fit both α(t) and D(t) by the classical Avrami model [45], = − −Φ 1 e ktc, here Φ is the degree of cure and k and c are fitting
parameters. We found the curves from DSC and resistance measurement can be fitted by the Avrami model with similar c values: c=1.2 for room temperature curing and c=1.5 for high temperature curing (as shown in Complementary Fig. S9). The only difference between DSC and resistance measurement was the value of k. For room temperature curing, kDSC= 2.1 and kCNT-FS= 0.61, while for high temperature curing, kDSC= 22 and kCNT-FS= 3.0. This fitting result suggests that DSC and CNT-FS both captured the essential curing mechanism of the resin but there is a rate difference between DSC and CNT-FS. This discrepancy can be caused by different measurement mechanism of DSC and CNT-FS. The former captures the exothermic heat, and the latter relates the shrinkage effect induced by cross-linking reaction. Based on this consideration, a correction factor n has been added in Equation (2) to remedy the mismatched time scale, which follows
= − − Δ Δ Δ Δ

With the fitted n=0.4 (0.3) for room temperature (60 °C) condition, we found a good agreement between α(t) and the corrected D(t) (as shown in red circles and squares in Fig. 6(b). With further studies to understand the strong correlation, the CNT-FS technique can potentially offer a unique capability of in situ monitoring the curing kinetics of composite materials, which cannot be readily accessed by other commonly used techniques, e.g., DSC, DMA, infrared and dielectric spectroscopy [46].
As compared to the previously developed CNM based sensors, the most significant advantage of the CNT-FS is that it can be easily and noninvasively integrated into a composite structure at desired orientations and locations for mapping and detecting the local status of resin flow, e.g. position of resin head, partially wetted areas and dry spots. To demonstrate this point, a series of parallel wire electrodes were introduced to partition the long fiber sensor into five local sensors. As demonstrated in Fig. 7(a), the sensor named S-1, S-2, S-3, S-4 and S-5 have been assigned with the sequence from right to left based on the resin flow direction indicated by red arrows. To mimic the possible event of dry spots and partially wetted areas, a circular and a half circular polyimide tape have been used to fully (for S-2) or partially (for S-4) seal the sensor inside to block the local fabric region from normal resin wetting. Fig. 7(b) shows the real-time resistance change (ΔR/R0) recorded synchronously for all the five sensors when the part was subjected to resin infusion. Arrows marked in the plot were the indication of the moment the resin start wetting the corresponding local region. As clearly depicted, ΔR/R0 of each sensor was accordingly increased one after another following the wetting sequence, indicating the capture of dynamic position of resin head. In addition to resin head detection, the created dry spot and partially wetted area were clearly discernable. This was reflected by the substantially and mildly degraded ramping rate of ΔR/R0 in S-2 (red curve) and S-4 (blue curve) with different blocking strategies. It is also noted that, although S-2 has
been fully sealed, the resistance still slightly increased, which was apparently caused by incidental intra-roving flow of resin diffused axially from the outer region. With the unique performance, one can nicely identify varied flowing status of resin registered by respective resistance changes of the deployed local sensors.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, three representative CNMs, i.e. CNT, rGO and CF have been selected and compared to assemble the embeddable fiber sensors for in situ monitoring and evaluating the health states of composites during the whole manufacturing process. With varied structure and performance, CNM sensors are capable of monitoring different stages of VARTM, including resin infusion, gelation and curing, which is highly valuable and critical for quality assurance of the host composites. Systematically studied through SEM, Raman and EDX, detailed morphology and packing structure have been revealed for understanding the substantial difference in sensing performance. Comparing to CF and rGO with continuous and densely packed graphitic structure, we believe that the loosely packed CNT network with comparatively large pore size is the major contribution for the markedly enhanced sensitivity. More importantly, the embedded CNT-FS with continuous length in composites can be partitioned into a series of local-sensors with customizable locations and configurations. As a result, local status of the resin flow can be revealed to pinpoint the problematic regions, such as dry spots and partially wetted areas. The multipurpose sensing capabilities in conjunction with their unique scalability and noninvasiveness make CNM fiber sensors highly valuable for next-generation smart composites with life-long self-sensing capabilities.

referenceMentions.context: In addition to traditionally adopted technology for structural health monitoring (SHM), including metallic strain gage [1], metal oxide thin/thick film [2], optical fiber

[3], piezoelectric [4], eddy-current [5] and magnetostrictive sensors [6], carbon nanomaterials (CNM) enabled sensors or sensor systems are emerging as one of the most promising technology for self-sensing, identifying, quantifying and deciding the health states of FRPs by virtue of excellent mechanical robustness, structural non-invasiveness, interfacial conformability and high piezoresistive sensitivity [7–9].

metadata.abstractText: Carbon nanomaterials (CNM) based technology has offered a variety of promising strategies for self-sensing and diagnosing functionalities in polymeric composites. In comparison with studies about detecting deformations and cracks, monitoring the manufacturing stage of composites using CNMs is rather limited. Based on continuous fabrication, we systematically investigated carbon nanotubes (CNTs) coated, graphene coated and carbon fiber sensors for monitoring complete molding process of composites through the real-time resistance change. Comparing to graphene-coated and carbon fibers with densely and continuously packed graphitic structures, the CNT fiber sensor with entangled and loosely packed porous network shows far superior performance for sensing different processing stages of composites, including resin infusion, gelation and curing. The resistance decay of the CNT sensor agrees well with curing kinetics measured by differential scanning calorimetry. Versatile capabilities of the CNT sensor were further explored for identifying various flowing defects such as dry spots and partially infiltrated areas.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
